class.description: Advanced material in computer graphics, including in-depth treatments of techniques for realistic image synthesis, advanced geometric modeling methods, animation and dynamic simulation, scientific visualization, and high-performance graphics architectures.

class.name: Computer Systems Architecture
class.description: In this course, you will learn about the basic principles and current practices of computer architectures and organizations. At the end of this course, you will understand how and why computer hardware is organized so that it can rapidly execute a software program expressed in assembly language. You will also understand how computer hardware provides software with the illusion that fast memory and other resources are unlimited, even though they are not. Finally, you will learn how to quantitatively evaluate and improve computer system performance.

class.description: Implementation of basic data structures, including stacks, queues, lists, priority queues, trees, binary search trees, graphs, and sets. Recursion. Efficient sorting and searching algorithms. Hashing. Multithreaded programs.

class.name: Programming Languages
class.description: Survey of significant concepts underlying modern programming languages, including syntax, functions, expressions, types, polymorphism, assignment, procedures, pointers, encapsulation, classes, and inheritance, with some discussion of implementation issues. Prominent programming paradigms, such as sequential, concurrent, object-oriented, functional, and logic programming. Illustrative examples drawn from a variety of current languages.

faculty.research_area: Operating systems and large-scale distributed systems

class.name: Web Operating Systems
class.description: This course has two goals. First, as a group, we should define a research agenda in "web operating systems." Second, as individuals, this course should equip you to do "state of the art" experimental research on topics relating to large-scale distributed systems.

article.journal: IEEE Transactions on Parallel and Distributed Systems

conference.name: 2002 USENIX Operating Systems Design and Implementation (OSDI) conference

conference.presentation_title: TCP Nice: A Mechanism for Background Transfers

building.building_name: Applied Computational Engineering and Sciences Building

faculty.title: Professor

class.name: Formal Verification and Semantics
class.description: This course will survey the classic theory of Formal Verification, including the work of Floyd, Hoare, and Dijkstra. Related work on Computer Aided Verification, including the work of Pnueli, Emerson, Clarke, Sifakis, and Milner are also addresses. The emphasis will be on using and applying logic, lattice theory, and automata theory to program verification and semantics.

writing.title: On Model Checking for Non-Deterministic Infinite-State Systems
